bioghist.p: The contributions of Dorothy P. Miller (1931-) as an open space and conservation activist began over forty years ago with her interest in birds and a desire to preserve their natural habitats. Dorothy Miller acted as a leader in the fight to preserve the White Clay Creek from damming in the 1960s, which led to the creation of the bi-state preserve that is now White Clay Creek State Park in both Delaware and Pennsylvania. She has helped many public and private agencies see the value of land preservation in the State of Delaware, as well as in Pennsylvania and Maryland. After the initial acquisition of 500 acres of parkland in Delaware, then known as Carpenter State Park, she remained active in lobbying for the purchase of additional lands along and in the area of the White Clay Creek, which now covers over 3,800 acres. In addition to her work at White Clay Creek, Dorothy Miller, with the support of the many groups to which she belongs, has also assisted and lobbied for the creation and preservation of many other areas and parks, including Middle Run, Coverdale, and the seven acre tract of land that was designated as Dorothy P. Miller Park by the City of Newark in 2006.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Dorothy P. Miller documenting Miller's activities related to environmental and local development issues. Materials include: correspondence; published reports; drafts of legislation; maps and plans; newspaper clippings; and programs. Organizations and issues represented in the collection include the Coalition for Natural Stream Valleys, Inc.; the Sierra Club; White Clay Creek State Park and the proposed White Clay Creek Dam; Fox Den Road Bridge; Cool Run Drainage; I-95 bridges; and the Deerfield Country Club.
